sentences.sentence: Australia has led the world in suppressing COVID-19 and reopening its economy.
But the good news on the economy and jobs has been bought with borrowed money that will have to be repaid.

Economic vandals would seek to sabotage this by ratcheting up the national wage floor by 3.5 per cent just as many small businesses, particularly in hospitality, entertainment and tourism, are battling to stay afloat after such a horror year.That's what the ACTU is demanding from the Fair Work Commission after the tribunal's low-quality decision in the middle of last year's pandemic crisis to increase the minimum wage by 1.75 per cent.

That increase rightly produced the first dissenting opinion, from economist Mark Wooden, on the commission's minimum wage panel in 30 years.The ACTU's latest demand would lift the minimum wage by $26.38 a week from $753.80, or $39,197.60 a year.Only 1.7 per cent of workers actually earn this basic amount.
And many of them do not come from poor households.

But the unique effect of Australia's minimum wage, already the highest in the world on purchasing power parity, is to drive up the pay of another 2.2 million workers on awards that are geared to it.Two-thirds of those workers would not be considered low earners, stretching right up to more than $180,000 a year for airline pilots who still have a job.Much of the good news on jobs is already over.
Unemployment stands at 5.8 per cent, but there are still 805,000 Australians out of work, or 90,000 more than pre-pandemic.
Anyone would have taken that result a year ago, amid forecasts that unemployment could jump to 10 per cent or more.
Yet with the budget-busting JobKeeper ending last month, the jobless rate could stall or edge up in coming months.Yes, as the ACTU argues, the economy is tipped to grow strongly over the next year.
But this will still not make up for the lost production and national income following the record 7 per cent quarterly contraction a year ago.
The unions say the commission must ordain the 3.5 per cent increase to reverse low wage growth, and raise demand in the broader economy.
But both are feeble arguments to artificially lift the wage floor so far in advance of inflation.
Despite still being on the edge of a pandemic abyss, the commission last July went ahead with a 1.75 per cent increase for 2020, staggered to mollify those businesses struggling to survive.

Unlike with a Labor government after the early 1980s recession, the unions are refusing to consider a nominal wage freeze and real wage cuts to get more people off the dole queues.With the household savings ratio sitting at a high 12 per cent, cashed up on JobKeeper and other government supports, wage increases are not needed to seed demand.

If consumers are going to be spooked by anything, it will be the small businesses that finally give up and lay off their workers if these wage demands are listened to.There is a mechanism for delivering wage increases and lower unemployment: productivity-based enterprise bargaining.
But that has been broken by the unions, Labor and the FWC.
Paul Keating, who created the system, says it has become legalistic and is not working as intended.
As a result, growth in productivity and wages are lower than in the reform era of the 1990s to the early 2000s.

Yet Labor and the unions forced the Morrison government to pull even modest reforms of the enterprise bargaining system from its failed omnibus industrial relations bill last month.This risks leaving taxpayers borrowing from the future to pay workers higher wages now.

Instead, Australia should focus on reducing its cost base and sharpening its productivity in order to sustainably support a high-wage economy into the future.The lack of any genuine policy reform agenda just leaves the Reserve Bank printing funny money in order to artificially suppress interest rates that the International Monetary Fund warns could end up inflating and then pricking Australia's housing price bubble in a "disorderly" way.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
